title: Jeremiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 22.

questions.question: Who is Jeremiah instructed to speak to in Jeremiah 22:1?
options: The king of Judah
The priests of Israel
The people of Egypt
The elders of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Judah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah is told to go down to the house of the king of Judah and speak there the word of the LORD, as stated in Jeremiah 22:1.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22:3, what are the people commanded to do?
options: Execute judgment and righteousness
Build large houses and chambers
Gather riches and gold
Worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment and righteousness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:3 commands to execute judgment and righteousness, deliver the spoiled out of the hand of the oppressor, and do no wrong or violence.

questions.question: What will happen if the people do not hear the words of the LORD, according to Jeremiah 22:5?
options: The house shall become a desolation
They will prosper and multiply
The gates will be closed forever
The king will be exalted
questions.correctAnswer: The house shall become a desolation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:5 states that if the people do not hear the words, the house shall become a desolation by the LORD's oath.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 22:6, what does the LORD compare the king's house of Judah to?
options: Gilead and the head of Lebanon
A mighty fortress
A flowing river
A barren desert
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead and the head of Lebanon
questions.explanation: The LORD says in Jeremiah 22:6 that the king's house of Judah is to Him like Gilead and the head of Lebanon.

questions.question: What will destroyers do to the choice cedars according to Jeremiah 22:7?
options: Cut them down and cast them into the fire
Build houses from them
Use them for sacrifices
Plant more cedars nearby
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them down and cast them into the fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:7 states that destroyers will cut down the choice cedars and cast them into the fire as a form of judgment.

questions.question: Why will many nations ask the reason for the LORD's actions upon the city, according to Jeremiah 22:8-9?
options: Because they forsook the covenant and worshipped other gods
Because they built large houses
Because they defeated their enemies
Because they made alliances with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Because they forsook the covenant and worshipped other gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:8-9 explains that the nations will ask why the LORD did this, and the answer is because the people forsook the covenant of the LORD and served other gods.

questions.question: What is Jeremiah told not to weep for in Jeremiah 22:10?
options: The dead
The living
The city walls
The king's treasures
questions.correctAnswer: The dead
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:10 says not to weep for the dead or bemoan him, but rather to weep for the one who goes away and will not return.

questions.question: What fate is foretold for Shallum son of Josiah in Jeremiah 22:11-12?
options: He shall not return to his land and shall die in captivity
He shall reign for many years
He will build a great temple
He will lead a victorious army
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not return to his land and shall die in captivity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:11-12 states that Shallum will not return to his land but die where he is taken captive and never see the land again.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22:13, what is condemned about the man who builds his house by unrighteousness?
options: He uses his neighbor's service without paying wages
He prays to God regularly
He feeds the poor
He builds a house for the widows
questions.correctAnswer: He uses his neighbor's service without paying wages
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:13 condemns the man who builds by unrighteousness and uses his neighbor's service without wages or proper payment.

questions.question: What question does the LORD ask in Jeremiah 22:15 about reigning?
options: Shalt thou reign because thou closest thyself in cedar?
Shalt thou reign because thou have many servants?
Shalt thou reign because thou art wealthy?
Shalt thou reign because thou hast many children?
questions.correctAnswer: Shalt thou reign because thou closest thyself in cedar?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:15 asks if one shall reign just because they have adorned themselves in cedar, questioning the basis of true leadership.

questions.question: What did the father of the one who builds with cedar do, according to Jeremiah 22:15-16?
options: He ate, drank, and did judgment and justice
He built large palaces
He amassed great wealth
He went to war often
questions.correctAnswer: He ate, drank, and did judgment and justice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:15-16 states the father ate and drank and did judgment and justice, and then it was well with him, highlighting righteous leadership.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22:19 says Jehoiakim will be buried with honor in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:19 states Jehoiakim will be buried with the burial of an ass, drawn and cast forth beyond the gates of Jerusalem, indicating dishonor.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22:21 says that the king obeyed God's voice from his youth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:21 says the king did not obey God's voice and refused to hear despite being spoken to in prosperity.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22:30 declares that no descendant of Coniah will prosper sitting on the throne of David.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:30 states that no man of Coniah's seed shall prosper sitting upon the throne of David or ruling in Judah anymore.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 22:24: 'As I live, saith the LORD, though Coniah the son of Jehoiakim king of Judah were the ______ upon my right hand, yet would I pluck thee thence;'
options: signet
king
priest
prophet
questions.correctAnswer: signet
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:24 uses the word 'signet' to describe Coniah as a signet upon God's right hand, yet He would pluck him away.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with integrity at work, tempted to exploit others for personal gain. Based on Jeremiah 22, what biblical truth would you share about work ethic and honesty?
options: Do no wrong or violence to the stranger, fatherless, or widow and pay wages for work done
Build large houses and decorate them finely to show success
Ignore the poor and needy and seek personal wealth
Focus only on your own prosperity and ignore justice
questions.correctAnswer: Do no wrong or violence to the stranger, fatherless, or widow and pay wages for work done
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:3 and 22:13 teach us to execute judgment and righteousness, deliver the oppressed, and pay wages for work done without exploiting others. This shows the importance of integrity and fairness in work.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 emphasize the importance of justice and care for the vulnerable in leadership?
options: By commanding to judge the cause of the poor and needy
By encouraging leaders to seek wealth and power
By focusing on military strength over justice
By promoting worship of other gods for prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: By commanding to judge the cause of the poor and needy
questions.explanation: Verse 16 highlights that judging the cause of the poor and needy brings well-being and is true knowledge of God, showing leadership must prioritize righteousness and care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because of consequences for past disobedience. What hope does Jeremiah 22 offer about repentance and God's covenant?
options: If you execute judgment and righteousness, kings will sit again on David's throne
Once desolation comes, there is no hope for restoration
God will only bless those who build wide houses
Disobedience has no consequences
questions.correctAnswer: If you execute judgment and righteousness, kings will sit again on David's throne
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:4 promises that if God’s commands for justice are followed, restoration will come with kings sitting on David’s throne, indicating hope through obedience.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 instruct believers to respond to the temptation of covetousness and violence?
options: Avoid shedding innocent blood and oppression as these are condemned by the Lord
Pursue wealth at all costs to secure your future
Ignore the poor and focus on your own success
Use violence to maintain power
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid shedding innocent blood and oppression as these are condemned by the Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 17 warns against covetousness and violence, showing that God calls His people to reject oppression and cherish justice and peace.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 22 teach about humility and contentment in leadership?
options: True success comes from doing justice and righteousness, not from fine houses or luxury
Building a wide house is a sign of God's blessing
Ignoring justice brings prosperity
Seeking personal glory is the way to reign
questions.correctAnswer: True success comes from doing justice and righteousness, not from fine houses or luxury
questions.explanation: Verses 14-16 contrast building luxurious homes with the importance of justice and righteousness, teaching humility and contentment over outward displays.

questions.question: A believer is grieving over a lost loved one who was unfaithful. What counsel from Jeremiah 22 could you share about mourning and hope?
options: Weep not for the dead but for those who depart and will not return
Lament excessively for the dead as they will return
Ignore the loss and move on quickly
Hope that the faithless will prosper
questions.correctAnswer: Weep not for the dead but for those who depart and will not return
questions.explanation: Verse 10 explains to weep not for the dead but for those who leave and will never return, highlighting the seriousness of spiritual exile and the need to focus on repentance and return to God.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 22 teach about God's discipline when His people forsake His covenant?
options: God will make the city desolate and send destroyers against it
God will ignore their sins and prosper them
God will grant them long life without repentance
God will bless them with wealth despite disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God will make the city desolate and send destroyers against it
questions.explanation: Verses 5, 6, and 7 explain that forsaking God's covenant leads to desolation and enemies destroying the city, showing the reality of divine discipline.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 illustrate the importance of obedience to God's voice from youth?
options: Obedience from youth leads to prosperity; ignoring God's voice leads to downfall
Obedience is optional and has no consequences
Youthful disobedience is easily forgiven without impact
Prosperity comes despite disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience from youth leads to prosperity; ignoring God's voice leads to downfall
questions.explanation: Verse 21 describes a pattern of disobedience from youth leading to negative consequences, teaching the value of early obedience to God.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22 encourages leaders to seek justice for the poor and needy as a demonstration of knowing God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that judging the cause of the poor and needy is to know God, underscoring justice as a mark of true knowledge of Him.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22 shows that God promises the descendants of Coniah will prosper on David’s throne.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 30 declares that no descendant of Coniah will prosper or sit on David’s throne, revealing God’s judgment on that lineage.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand stewardship and generosity from Jeremiah 22. Which verse best teaches about fairness in labor and reward?
options: Woe to him who uses his neighbor's service without wages
Build wide houses and decorate with cedar
Seek power to reign at all costs
Ignore the needs of the widow and fatherless
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to him who uses his neighbor's service without wages
questions.explanation: Verse 13 condemns exploiting workers by withholding wages, teaching fairness and generosity in stewardship.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 instruct us about the consequences of forsaking God’s covenant on a communal level?
options: Many nations will pass by and question why the LORD has done this to the city
The city will prosper and be envied by others
The city will be blessed with peace and safety
The covenant can be ignored without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Many nations will pass by and question why the LORD has done this to the city
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 9 describe nations passing by and questioning the desolation because the people forsook God's covenant and worshipped other gods.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 22 teach about humility in leadership compared to relying on outward appearances like cedar paneling and painted chambers?
options: Righteous judgment and justice are more important than luxurious decorations
Luxury and grandeur guarantee a good reign
Outward beauty ensures God's favor
Ignoring justice leads to prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Righteous judgment and justice are more important than luxurious decorations
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 contrast building luxurious houses with actual justice and righteousness, showing true leadership is not about outward appearance but inner justice.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 22 teaches that if the king and people execute judgment and righteousness, then kings will enter by the gates of this house, sitting on the throne of David, riding in _____ and on horses.
options: chariots
carriages
elephants
ships
questions.correctAnswer: chariots
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:4 specifically mentions kings riding in chariots and horses, symbolizing restoration and blessing upon following God's commands.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 demonstrate the importance of trusting God's sovereign justice during trials and judgment?
options: God will execute judgment on unfaithful leaders and bring desolation for their wickedness
Human strength and alliances determine the outcome
Ignoring God leads to blessings
Judgment can be avoided by wealth
questions.correctAnswer: God will execute judgment on unfaithful leaders and bring desolation for their wickedness
questions.explanation: Throughout the chapter, especially verses 18-26, God pronounces judgment on kings who acted wickedly, showing His sovereign justice during trials.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 22.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 22:3, what social justice actions does the LORD command the king of Judah to execute?
options: Execute judgment and righteousness, deliver the spoiled from the oppressor, do no wrong to the stranger, fatherless, or widow, and do not shed innocent blood
Build large temples and offer many sacrifices
Gather armies to defend the city from invaders
Increase trade and alliances with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment and righteousness, deliver the spoiled from the oppressor, do no wrong to the stranger, fatherless, or widow, and do not shed innocent blood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:3 explicitly commands the king to act justly by delivering the oppressed and protecting vulnerable groups, emphasizing social justice as a covenantal obligation.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22:5, what consequence does the LORD declare if the king of Judah refuses to heed His words?
options: The house shall become a desolation
The king will be blessed with long life
The people will prosper and multiply
The temple will be filled with glory
questions.correctAnswer: The house shall become a desolation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:5 contains a solemn oath from the LORD warning that disobedience will result in desolation of the king's house, indicating judgment for ignoring divine commands.

questions.question: In verse 6, the LORD compares the king's house of Judah to what geographical features, and what is the irony in this comparison?
options: Gilead and the head of Lebanon; though mighty, it will become a wilderness
The Nile and the Euphrates; though flowing with life, it will dry up
Mount Sinai and Mount Zion; though holy, it will be defiled
The Jordan River and the Dead Sea; though fertile, it will become barren
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead and the head of Lebanon; though mighty, it will become a wilderness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:6 uses a simile comparing the king's house to prominent regions symbolizing strength and beauty, but ironically declares it will be made desolate, highlighting the judgment theme.

questions.question: What reason do the nations give for the destruction of Jerusalem as recorded in Jeremiah 22:9?
options: Because they have forsaken the covenant of the LORD their God, and worshipped other gods
Because they failed to build strong city walls
Because they refused to pay tribute to Babylon
Because they allied with Egypt instead of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have forsaken the covenant of the LORD their God, and worshipped other gods
questions.explanation: Verse 9 reveals the theological interpretation of Jerusalem's fall: covenant unfaithfulness and idolatry caused the LORD to bring judgment.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22:10, for whom should people weep, and why is this significant in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Weep sore for him that goeth away, because he shall return no more
Weep for the dead, because they have completed their journey
Weep for the king's servants, because they are loyal
Weep for the temple priests, because they intercede for the people
questions.correctAnswer: Weep sore for him that goeth away, because he shall return no more
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:10 contrasts mourning customs by emphasizing sorrow for those exiled who will not return, reflecting the trauma of forced displacement in the ancient world.

questions.question: What prophecy concerning Shallum son of Josiah is given in Jeremiah 22:11-12?
options: He shall not return to Jerusalem but die in captivity
He shall reign long and prosper in Jerusalem
He shall build a new temple for the LORD
He shall defeat the Babylonian army
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not return to Jerusalem but die in captivity
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 predict that Shallum (Jehoahaz) will be taken captive and die in a foreign land, illustrating the historical exile during Babylonian domination.

questions.question: Jeremiah 22:13-14 condemns the construction of houses built by what kind of means?
options: Unrighteousness and wrong, exploiting neighbors without paying wages
Using foreign materials imported from Egypt
Building too small and inadequate shelters
Constructing houses without a temple in the city
questions.correctAnswer: Unrighteousness and wrong, exploiting neighbors without paying wages
questions.explanation: These verses criticize the social injustice of exploiting workers while building luxurious homes, highlighting the ethical failures of Judah’s leadership.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22:15-16 contrast the reign of the current king with that of his father?
options: The father ate, drank, and did justice, which brought well-being, while the son focuses on luxury and injustice
The father was a warrior king, but the son is a peaceful ruler
The father built temples, but the son destroyed them
The father forsook the LORD, but the son was faithful
questions.correctAnswer: The father ate, drank, and did justice, which brought well-being, while the son focuses on luxury and injustice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:15-16 praises the father’s righteous leadership as the reason for prosperity, implicitly condemning the son’s failure to uphold justice.

questions.question: What character traits are attributed to Jehoiakim in Jeremiah 22:17, leading to his condemnation?
options: Covetousness, shedding innocent blood, oppression, and violence
Humility, obedience, and justice
Mercy, charity, and faithfulness
Wisdom, patience, and peace
questions.correctAnswer: Covetousness, shedding innocent blood, oppression, and violence
questions.explanation: Verse 17 describes Jehoiakim’s heart and eyes as set on greed and violence, providing the moral basis for divine judgment.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 22:19 say about the burial of Jehoiakim, and what does this symbolize culturally?
options: He shall be buried with the burial of an ass, drawn and cast forth beyond the gates of Jerusalem, symbolizing disgrace
He shall receive a royal burial in the temple, symbolizing honor
He shall be buried in the family tomb, symbolizing continuity
He shall be cremated, symbolizing purification
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be buried with the burial of an ass, drawn and cast forth beyond the gates of Jerusalem, symbolizing disgrace
questions.explanation: This verse predicts an ignominious burial, a sign of shame and rejection by the community, reflecting ancient Near Eastern customs of honor and dishonor.

questions.question: Jeremiah 22:20-22 uses poetic language calling out Lebanon and Bashan. What is the purpose of this imagery?
options: To lament the destruction of Judah’s allies and express the inevitability of judgment
To celebrate the victory over Babylon
To praise the fertility of the land
To call for a festival of thanksgiving
questions.correctAnswer: To lament the destruction of Judah’s allies and express the inevitability of judgment
questions.explanation: The imagery of Lebanon and Bashan mourning reflects the loss of Judah’s strength and support, underscoring the depth of divine judgment.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 22:24-27, what is the significance of the LORD stating He would pluck Coniah from His right hand despite the signet?
options: It symbolizes the revocation of royal authority and covenant favor despite apparent legitimacy
It means Coniah will be exalted above all kings
It indicates Coniah’s eternal reign on the throne of David
It predicts Coniah’s peaceful reign and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the revocation of royal authority and covenant favor despite apparent legitimacy
questions.explanation: The signet symbolizes authority and favor, but the LORD’s removal of Coniah despite this signifies judgment and loss of kingship.

questions.question: What rhetorical device is primarily used in Jeremiah 22:29 with the repetition of the word 'earth' and what is its effect?
options: Anaphora, emphasizing the urgency and solemnity of the LORD’s word
Simile, comparing the earth to a woman in travail
Metaphor, describing the earth as a vessel
Hyperbole, exaggerating the destruction of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Anaphora, emphasizing the urgency and solemnity of the LORD’s word
questions.explanation: The triple repetition is an example of anaphora, a Hebrew poetic device used to command attention and emphasize the importance of the message.

questions.question: What is the prophetic verdict pronounced on Coniah in Jeremiah 22:30 and how does it relate to the Davidic covenant?
options: He is declared childless and will not prosper on David’s throne, ending his line's rule
He will reign forever with great success
He will establish a new covenant
He will restore the temple and bring peace
questions.correctAnswer: He is declared childless and will not prosper on David’s throne, ending his line's rule
questions.explanation: Verse 30 pronounces a curse breaking the dynastic promise of the Davidic covenant for Coniah’s descendants, marking a theological turning point.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 22:21 indicates that the king was receptive to God's words during his prosperity.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:21 states that the king refused to hear God's voice even in prosperity, showing persistent disobedience.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22, what is the primary responsibility given to the king of Judah and his officials?
options: Execute judgment and righteousness
Build wide houses and large chambers
Amass wealth and power
Form alliances with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment and righteousness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:3 instructs the king and his officials to execute judgment and righteousness, deliver the oppressed, and do no violence or shed innocent blood. This aligns with God's consistent call for justice and righteousness as seen in Psalm 72:1-4, Isaiah 1:17, Micah 6:8, and Proverbs 21:3.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare for the house of Judah if they fail to obey His commands in Jeremiah 22?
options: The house shall become a desolation
They will gain many allies
The king will reign forever
Their enemies will be defeated
questions.correctAnswer: The house shall become a desolation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:5 states that if they do not hear God's words, the house will become a desolation. This reflects the biblical principle that disobedience leads to judgment, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15, 2 Chronicles 36:17-21, Ezekiel 21:3-4, and Hosea 4:6.

questions.question: What does God compare the king's house of Judah to in verse 6, emphasizing His judgment?
options: Gilead and the head of Lebanon
A mighty fortress
A flourishing vineyard
A city on a hill
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead and the head of Lebanon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:6 describes the king's house as 'Gilead' and 'the head of Lebanon,' which are symbols of strength and majesty, yet God declares He will make it a wilderness. This illustrates God's sovereign power to humble the proud, as echoed in Isaiah 10:33-34, Ezekiel 17:22-24, Psalm 75:6-7, and Habakkuk 2:4.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 22:9, what reason is given for the judgment upon the great city?
options: They have forsaken the covenant of the LORD and worshipped other gods
They have built their houses with cedar
They have amassed wealth unjustly
They have refused to listen to foreign prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They have forsaken the covenant of the LORD and worshipped other gods
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states their judgment is because they forsook God's covenant and worshipped other gods, reflecting the biblical theme of covenant faithfulness and idolatry consequences seen in Exodus 34:14-16, Judges 2:11-13, 1 Kings 11:4-6, and Hosea 8:4-6.

questions.question: What fate does God declare for Shallum, the son of Josiah, in Jeremiah 22?
options: He shall die in captivity and never see his native land again
He shall reign long over Judah
He shall be restored to the throne
He shall be honored among his people
questions.correctAnswer: He shall die in captivity and never see his native land again
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:11-12 prophesies that Shallum will not return to his land but will die in the place of captivity, a warning consistent with God's judgment on disobedient kings seen in 2 Kings 24:15-16, Psalm 137:1-4, Daniel 1:1-7, and Ezekiel 12:13.

questions.question: What is condemned about the way some build their houses in Jeremiah 22:13-14?
options: Building by unrighteousness and exploiting labor without wages
Building with poor materials
Building without God's blessing
Building houses too small for their family
questions.correctAnswer: Building by unrighteousness and exploiting labor without wages
questions.explanation: The text condemns building houses through injustice and withholding wages from laborers, highlighting God’s concern for social justice seen in Leviticus 19:13, Deuteronomy 24:14-15, James 5:4, and Proverbs 22:22-23.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 22, what is the relationship between just rule and prosperity as illustrated by the king's father?
options: Righteous judgment and justice led to well-being
Wealth and cedar-paneled chambers brought success
Military conquest ensured peace
Political alliances secured the throne
questions.correctAnswer: Righteous judgment and justice led to well-being
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:15-16 contrasts material luxury with righteous justice, affirming that the king's father prospered because he judged justly, consistent with Proverbs 29:2, Psalm 72:12-14, Isaiah 32:1-2, and Micah 6:8.

questions.question: What character flaws does God accuse Jehoiakim of in Jeremiah 22:17?
options: Covetousness, shedding innocent blood, oppression, and violence
Humility and faithfulness
Generosity and kindness
Wisdom and discernment
questions.correctAnswer: Covetousness, shedding innocent blood, oppression, and violence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:17 identifies these sins, which are universally condemned in scripture as offenses against God’s holiness (Exodus 20:13, Proverbs 6:16-19, Isaiah 1:15-17, Matthew 23:23).

questions.question: What does God declare about the mourning for Jehoiakim upon his death in Jeremiah 22?
options: They shall not lament for him or his glory
There will be great mourning and lamentation
He will be honored as a righteous king
His death will bring joy to the people
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not lament for him or his glory
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:18 says no lamentation will be made for Jehoiakim, indicating divine judgment and disgrace, paralleled in Ezekiel 24:16-18, Amos 6:10, 2 Samuel 1:17-27, and Nahum 1:15.

questions.question: How will Jehoiakim be buried according to Jeremiah 22:19?
options: With the burial of an ass, dragged and cast beyond the gates of Jerusalem
With royal honors in the city
In the family tomb
In a secret location
questions.correctAnswer: With the burial of an ass, dragged and cast beyond the gates of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:19 describes a humiliating burial, symbolizing disgrace and rejection, consistent with Old Testament examples of cursed burial such as 1 Samuel 31:8-13, Ezekiel 32:18-32, and Numbers 19:11-13.

questions.question: What does God say about Coniah (Jehoiachin) in Jeremiah 22:24-30?
options: Though he is a signet on God's right hand, God will pluck him off and exile him
He will prosper and establish a lasting dynasty
He will return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple
He will be exalted above all kings of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Though he is a signet on God's right hand, God will pluck him off and exile him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:24-25 declares that despite his position, God will remove Coniah and exile him, signifying judgment. This is echoed in 2 Kings 24:8-17, Ezekiel 17:15-21, Psalm 89:38-45, and Isaiah 22:21-25.

questions.question: What is the ultimate decree about Coniah's descendants in Jeremiah 22:30?
options: No man of his seed shall prosper sitting on the throne of David
His lineage will reign forever
His descendants will be priests and prophets
His seed will return to the land in triumph
questions.correctAnswer: No man of his seed shall prosper sitting on the throne of David
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:30 proclaims Coniah childless in terms of royal succession, indicating no descendant will prosper on David’s throne, which reflects God's judgment that ended this line’s royal legitimacy. This theme is consistent with 1 Chronicles 3:16-17, Ezekiel 21:25-27, Psalm 89:30-37, and Luke 1:32-33 pointing to the Messianic line.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 22 teach about God's holiness and justice through the judgments pronounced?
options: God is holy and just and punishes sin, especially injustice and idolatry
God overlooks the sins of kings
God prefers mercy without judgment
God’s justice is delayed indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and just and punishes sin, especially injustice and idolatry
questions.explanation: The chapter consistently shows God’s holy justice in punishing covenant unfaithfulness and social injustice (Jeremiah 22:3, 9, 17, 30). This accords with Leviticus 19:15, Romans 2:5-8, Hebrews 12:6, and Revelation 15:3-4.

questions.question: What messianic or Christological implication can be drawn from Jeremiah 22’s emphasis on righteous judgment and the failure of David's descendants?
options: The need for a perfect righteous King, fulfilled in Christ
The end of David’s line means no future hope
The kingship is irrelevant to salvation
The Messiah will be a political conqueror only
questions.correctAnswer: The need for a perfect righteous King, fulfilled in Christ
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22’s judgment on David’s failing descendants emphasizes the need for a perfect ruler who executes justice, a role fulfilled by Christ (Isaiah 9:6-7, Jeremiah 23:5-6, Luke 1:32-33, Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 22 address the theme of covenant faithfulness in relation to national prosperity?
options: Faithfulness to God’s covenant results in blessing, while unfaithfulness brings desolation
Prosperity depends on military strength alone
Covenants are irrelevant to national success
Prosperity comes from alliances with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God’s covenant results in blessing, while unfaithfulness brings desolation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 22:8-9 links forsaking the covenant with destruction, exemplifying the biblical principle that covenant faithfulness leads to blessing (Deuteronomy 28:1-14, Psalm 89:34-37, 2 Chronicles 7:14, Hebrews 8:6-13).
